Tsunamis are triggered by
intense underwater activity,

usually an earthquake, or
an underwater volcanic eruption.

These events displace
huge volumes of water,

pushing it up from the
ocean's floor to its surface.
But when gravity pulls it back down,

all this built up energy
is released outwards,

forming deadly waves
that grow stronger
as they ripple across the ocean.

A tsunami's waves can be
100 km (62 miles) long,

and sometimes taller
than 30 meters (100 ft)!

They can travel across

of a jet airplane.
